intro: Anomospermum chloranthum subsp. occidentale, commonly known as the western ghost tree, is a shrub native to arid and semi-arid regions of southern Africa. It belongs to the family Anacardiaceae, which includes plants such as the cashew and sumac. The plant is characterized by its small, clustered leaves and yellowish-green flowers that are often inconspicuous. Its fruits are small, fleshy drupes that may be eaten by local wildlife. The species is adapted to harsh environments, showcasing resilience through its deep root system and water-storing tissues.
